column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=The contents of the petition were to this purpose
#Text=‘ O our Lord , and Sovereign Prince Emmanuel , the potent , the long-suffering Prince !
#Text=grace is poured into thy lips , and to thee belong mercy and forgiveness , though we have rebelled against thee .
#Text=We , who are no more worthy to be called thy Mansoul , nor yet fit to partake of common benefits , do beseech thee , and thy Father by thee , to do away our transgressions .

#Text=We confess that thou mightest cast us away for them ; but do it not for thy name ’s sake : let the Lord rather take an opportunity , at our miserable condition , to let out his bowels and compassions to us .
#Text=We are compassed on every side , Lord ; our own backslidings reprove us ; our Diabolonians within our town fright us ; and the army of the angel of the bottomless pit distresses us .
#Text=Thy grace can be our salvation , and whither to go but to thee we know not .
#Text=‘

#Text=Furthermore , O gracious Prince , we have weakened our captains , and they are discouraged , sick , and , of late , some of them grievously worsted and beaten out of the field by the power and force of the tyrant .
#Text=Yea , even those of our captains , in whose valour we did formerly use to put most of our confidence , they are as wounded men .
#Text=Besides , Lord , our enemies are lively , and they are strong ; they vaunt and boast themselves , and do threaten to part us among themselves for a booty .

#Text=They are fallen also upon us , Lord , with many thousand doubters , such as with whom we cannot tell what to do ; they are all grim-looked and unmerciful ones , and they bid defiance to us and thee .
#Text=‘ Our wisdom is gone , our power is gone , because thou art departed from us ; nor have we what we may call ours but sin , shame , and confusion of face for sin .
#Text=Take pity upon us , O Lord , take pity upon us , thy miserable town of Mansoul , and save us out of the hands of our enemies .
#Text=Amen . ’
#Text=This petition , as was touched afore , was handed by the Lord Secretary , and carried to the court by the brave and most stout Captain Credence .
#Text=Now he carried it out at Mouth-gate , ( for that , as I said , was the sally-port of the town , ) and he went and came to Emmanuel with it .
#Text=Now how it came out , I do not know ; but for certain it did , and that so far as to reach the ears of Diabolus .

#Text=Thus I conclude , because that the tyrant had it presently by the end , and charged the town of Mansoul with it , saying , ‘ Thou rebellious and stubborn-hearted Mansoul , I will make thee to leave off petitioning .
#Text=Art thou yet for petitioning ?
#Text=I will make thee to leave . ’
#Text=Yea , he also knew who the messenger was that carried the petition to the Prince , and it made him both to fear and rage .
#Text=Wherefore he commanded that his drum should be beat again , a thing that Mansoul could not abide to hear : but when Diabolus will have his drum beat , Mansoul must abide the noise .
#Text=Well , the drum was beat , and the Diabolonians were gathered together .

#Text=Then said Diabolus , ‘ O ye stout Diabolonians , be it known unto you , that there is treachery hatched against us in the rebellious town of Mansoul ; for albeit the town is in our possession , as you see , yet these miserable Mansoulians have attempted to dare , and have been so hardy as yet to send to the court to Emmanuel for help .
#Text=This I give you to understand , that ye may yet know how to carry it to the wretched town of Mansoul .

#Text=Wherefore , O my trusty Diabolonians , I command that yet more and more ye distress this town of Mansoul , and vex it with your wiles , ravish their women , deflower their virgins , slay their children , brain their ancients , fire their town , and what other mischief you can ; and let this be the reward of the Mansoulians from me , for their desperate rebellions against me . ’
#Text=This , you see , was the charge ; but something stepped in betwixt that and execution , for as yet there was but little more done than to rage .

#Text=Moreover , when Diabolus had done thus , he went the next way up to the castle gates , and demanded that , upon pain of death , the gates should be opened to him , and that entrance should be given him and his men that followed after .
#Text=To whom Mr. Godly-Fear replied , ( for he it was that had the charge of that gate , ) that the gate should not be opened unto him , nor to the men that followed after him .
#Text=He said , moreover , that Mansoul , when she had suffered awhile , should be made perfect , strengthened , settled .

#Text=Then said Diabolus , ‘ Deliver me , then , the men that have petitioned against me , especially Captain Credence , that carried it to your Prince ; deliver that varlet into my hands , and I will depart from the town . ’
#Text=Then up starts a Diabolonian , whose name was Mr. Fooling , and said , ‘ My lord offereth you fair : it is better for you that one man perish , than that your whole Mansoul should be undone . ’
#Text=But Mr. Godly-Fear made him this replication , ‘ How long will Mansoul be kept out of the dungeon , when she hath given up her faith to Diabolus !
#Text=As good lose the town , as lose Captain Credence ; for if one be gone the other must follow . ’
#Text=But to that Mr. Fooling said nothing .
